title: The death of eugenics is a matter of heated debate among historians of the subject. Haller and several others assert that it faded from mainstream U.S. thought even before becoming tainted by association with Nazi genocide, while several more recent cultural historians trace the enduring influence of eugenic doctrine throughout the twentieth century, connecting it to the success of Richard Herrnstein and Charles Murray’s 1994 bestseller The Bell Curve as well as the grand aspirations of the Human Genome Project
